title: Yoke of Babylon
shortSummary: Jeremiah 27 records God's command to the prophet Jeremiah to wear yokes and send them to surrounding nations as a symbol of submission to Babylonian rule. The chapter emphasizes God's sovereign control over nations and warns Judah and its neighbors to submit to Nebuchadnezzar, promising peace for those who obey and judgment for those who resist. It also condemns false prophets who oppose this divine decree.
timeline: c. 605 BC - Early reign of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, during the rise of Babylonian dominance under Nebuchadnezzar

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives and delivers God's message about submission to Babylon and the consequences of rebellion.

keyCharacters.name: Jehoiakim
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah at the beginning of this chapter, during whose reign Jeremiah receives this prophecy.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadnezzar
keyCharacters.description: King of Babylon described as God's servant, appointed to rule over the nations including Judah.

keyCharacters.name: Zedekiah
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who is instructed by Jeremiah to submit to Babylon to preserve life and land.

definitions.definition: A wooden frame placed on the necks of oxen to control and direct them; symbolically represents submission and servitude.
Individuals who claim to speak God's message; in this chapter, some are false prophets misleading the people.
The Babylonian king referred to as God's servant who is used to execute divine judgment and rule over nations.
Sacred temple objects used in worship, which were taken captive to Babylon as part of the judgment.

outline.heading: Jeremiah’s Yoke as a Symbol of Submission
outline.description: God commands Jeremiah to make yokes and send them to surrounding kings as a symbol that all lands are under Nebuchadnezzar’s authority, demonstrating God's sovereign control over nations.

outline.heading: Warning Against Rebellion and False Prophets
outline.description: God warns that nations refusing to serve Babylon will face punishment and instructs the people not to listen to false prophets who claim otherwise, emphasizing the certainty of Babylonian dominance.

outline.heading: Instructions to Zedekiah and the People
outline.description: Jeremiah relays God’s command to King Zedekiah and the people to submit to Babylon to avoid destruction, rejecting false hopes of immediate restoration.

outline.heading: Fate of the Temple Vessels
outline.description: God declares that the remaining temple vessels will be taken to Babylon and remain there until God’s appointed time for restoration, underscoring the reality of exile and future hope.

application: Submit to God-ordained authorities as an act of obedience and trust in His sovereign plan.
Discern and reject false teaching that contradicts God’s revealed word, especially regarding His purposes and discipline.
Trust God’s timing for restoration and deliverance even when circumstances seem dire or prolonged.
Pray for wisdom and humility to accept God’s correction and live in peace with others under His providence.

keyVerses.text: I have made the earth, the man and the beast that are upon the ground, by my great power and by my outstretched arm, and have given it unto whom it seemed meet unto me.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God's absolute sovereignty over creation and nations, establishing the foundation for His command to submit to Babylon.

keyVerses.text: And it shall come to pass, that the nation and kingdom which will not serve the same Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon, and that will not put their neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon, that nation will I punish, saith the LORD, with the sword, and with the famine, and with the pestilence, until I have consumed them by his hand.
keyVerses.significance: This verse clearly states the consequences of rebellion against God's appointed authority, emphasizing the certainty of divine judgment.

keyVerses.text: But the nations that bring their neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon, and serve him, those will I let remain still in their own land, saith the LORD; and they shall till it, and dwell therein.
keyVerses.significance: This verse offers hope and assurance that submission to God's will brings preservation and peace.
